summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of a motion to dismiss the superseding indictment against her. The core argument is that her prosecution is barred by the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, which included immunity for 'any potential co-conspirators of Epstein.' The memorandum contends the government breached this agreement and that the charges are legally flawed.

events.title: Execution of Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and his counsel entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, then led by R. Alexander Acosta. The agreement deferred federal prosecution in exchange for a state guilty plea and included a provision immunizing 'any potential co-conspirators of Epstein.'

events.title: Epstein's Florida State Guilty Plea
events.description: Following the NPA, Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to a single-count Florida state indictment and served 13 months in prison.

events.title: Miami Herald Article on Epstein Case
events.description: An explosive front-page article in the Miami Herald reported detailed allegations about Epstein's conduct, Acosta's handling of the investigation, and the terms of the NPA, reigniting public and legal scrutiny.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his jail cell while in federal custody, an event described by the then-Attorney General as a 'perfect storm of screw-ups.'

events.title: Arrest and Indictment of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The government arrested and indicted Ghislaine Maxwell on the exact anniversary of Epstein's indictment. The U.S. Attorney for the SDNY described it as the 'prequel' to the Epstein case.

events.title: DOJ OPR Report Release
events.description: The Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility released a report (executive summary made public) criticizing Acosta's 'poor judgment' and characterizing the Epstein NPA as a 'unique resolution' with 'unusual and problematic terms.'

keyFacts: The defense's primary argument is that a 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida explicitly states 'the United States ... will not institute any criminal charges against any potential co-conspirators of Epstein,' which they argue includes Ghislaine Maxwell and bars her prosecution.

The memorandum highlights that the NPA's immunity provision for Epstein himself is limited to prosecution 'in this District' (SDFL), but the co-conspirator immunity clause contains no such geographic limitation, referring broadly to 'the United States.'

The filing alleges the government's decision to prosecute Maxwell was a reactive response to the media frenzy and public embarrassment following Epstein's death in custody, rather than based on new evidence, stating the government sought 'to substitute our client for Jeffrey Epstein.'

The document references a DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility report that found former U.S. Attorney Acosta exercised 'poor judgment' and agreed to 'unusual and problematic terms' in the Epstein NPA, which it called a 'unique resolution.'

The defense argues that, at a minimum, the ambiguity in the NPA's co-conspirator immunity provision must be construed strictly against the government, warranting dismissal of the indictment or, alternatively, discovery and an evidentiary hearing on the parties' intent.
